conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to calculate the change in magnetic flux through the coil as it rotates around the z-axis. The magnetic flux is given by the product of the magnetic induction intensity and the area of the coil.
The coil is initially positioned such that the area is oriented with the z-axis as the normal. After rotating 60° downward, the area becomes oriented with the x-axis as the normal.
The area of the initial orientation is 0.4 m². The area of the final orientation is also 0.4 m².
The magnetic flux is given by the formula: Flux = B × Area.
Since the area remains the same, the change in flux is simply the difference in magnetic induction intensity.
Change in Flux = B × Initial Area - B × Final Area = 0.1 T × 0.4 m² - 0.1 T × 0.4 m² = 0.04 Wb.
Since the flux is a scalar quantity, the change in flux is 0.04 Wb.
The magnetic flux changes by 0.04 Wb.
